Read the report describing the information shown in the bar chart from the previous exercise again and click on all the verbs in the present simple. There are 18 examples. To see the IELTS Writing Task, click on the icon on the right.
Writing Task 1

section.p: The bar chart shows the amount of time that 16 to 24-year-olds in England spend per week on sport and exercise. It is clear from the chart that young women are less active in their leisure time than young men.

There is a striking difference between the percentages of men and women who prefer not to participate in sport in their free time. Almost half of young women devote no time at all to active leisure pursuits while this applies to only about a quarter of young men. There is a similar difference between the percentages of very active young people. Almost 1 in 5 men between the ages of 16 and 24 play sport for 7 or more hours a week. The figure for young women is only 5 per cent.

A closer examination of the figures for young people who actually play sport reveals that the greatest proportion dedicate between 1 and 3 hours per week to these pastimes. This is true for just over a fifth of both men and women.

The fact that only two-fifths of young women spend an hour or more a week on sport, compared to approximately two-thirds of young men, raises questions about how fit young women are in comparison to young men.

p.font: The bar chart in this exercise has no date so we can assume that the information relates to the present. It shows the situation at one point in time and does not show changes over time. This kind of chart is sometimes called a 'static' chart and simple tenses (rather than continuous or perfect tenses) are most appropriate when describing the information shown. In this case, we can use the present simple for most of the report.
